Scala.name: InstructionsDrawG

Python.name: InstructionsDrawG
Python.correction:
# BEGIN SOLUTION
brushDown()
left()
forward(4)
left()
forward(4)
left()
forward(4)
left()
forward()
forward()
left()
forward()
# back home 
brushUp()
right()
forward(2)
right()
forward()
left()
# END SOLUTION

initialWorlds.name: Training World
initialWorlds.about:
BuggleWorld

This world was invented by Lyn Turbak, at Wellesley College. It is full of Buggles, little animals understanding simple orders, and offers numerous possibilities of interaction with the world: taking or dropping objects, paint the ground, hit walls, etc.

Methods understood by buggles

Moving
(See also the note on exceptions, below)
Turn left
Turn right
Turn back
Moving forward
Moving back		 void left()
void right()
void back()
void forward() or void forward(int steps)
void backward() or void backward(int steps)
Get X coordinate
Get Y coordinate
Set X coordinate
Set Y coordinate
Set position		 int getX()
int getY()
void setX(int x)
void setY(int y)
void setPos(int x, int y)
Note that the point (0,0) is on the top left corner, as it is often the case in Computer Science.
Information on the buggle
Get the color of the body
Set the color of the body		 Color getBodyColor()
void setBodyColor(Color c)
Look for a wall forward
Look for a wall backward		 boolean isFacingWall()
boolean isBackingWall()
Get heading
Set heading
valid directions are:		 Direction getDirection()
void setDirection(Direction dir)
Direction.NORTH, Direction.EAST, Direction.SOUTH and Direction.WEST
Check whether the buggle is currently selected in the interface boolean isSelected()
About the brush
Brush down
Brush up
Get brush position		 void brushUp()
void brushDown()
boolean isBrushDown()
Change the brush color
Get the color of the brush		 void setBrushColor(Color c)
Color getBrushColor()
Interacting with the world
Get the color of the ground Color getGroundColor()
Look for a baggle on the ground
Look for a baggle in bag
Pickup a baggle
Drop a baggle
(see the note on exceptions)		 boolean isOverBaggle()
boolean isCarryingBaggle()
void pickupBaggle()
void dropBaggle()
 
Look for a message
Add a message
Read the message
Erase the message		 boolean isOverMessage()
void writeMessage(String msg)
String readMessage()
void clearMessage()

Valid colors

NameColor
Color.black  
Color.blue  
Color.cyan  
Color.darkGray  
Color.gray  
Color.green  
Color.lightGray 
Color.magenta  
Color.orange  
Color.pink  
Color.red  
Color.white  
Color.yellow  

Note on exceptions

Regular buggles throw a BuggleWallException exception if you ask them to traverse a wall. They throw a NoBaggleUnderBuggleException exception if you ask them to pickup a baggle from an empty cell, or a AlreadyHaveBaggleException exception if they already carry a baggle. Trying to drop a baggle on a cell already containing one throws an AlreadyHaveBaggleException exception. Dropping a baggle when you have none throws a DontHaveBaggleException.

SimpleBuggles (ie, the one used in first exercises) display an error message on problem so that you don't need to know what an exception is.

instructions.en:
Writing more complex programs

Now that we know how to draw things on the board, we'll enjoy this ability and draw a beautiful G on the board (check Objective panel for details on what is expected).

When you write a quite complex program, it is sometimes useful to add comments to simplify the code reviews afterward. Here for example, it's quite easy to get lost in the drawing process, and you may want to add comments like vertical bar done or finished drawing the G. Time to move back to initial position. Commenting your code is almost mandatory if you (or someone else) want to read it afterward, although over-commenting (describing obvious stuff) is a bad idea as the important idea get lost in the noise.

There is [!java]three[/!][!python|scala|c]two[/!] types of comments in [!thelang], instructing the [!java|scala|c]compiler[/!][!python]interpreter[/!] to not read the text you add for humans:

  • Comments on a single line. When the [!java|scala|c]compiler[/!][!python]interpreter[/!] encounters the symbol [!java|scala|c]//[/!][!python]#[/!], it ignores the end of the line.
  • Comments on several lines. The [!java|scala|c]compiler[/!][!python]interpreter[/!] ignores anything placed between [!java|scala|c]the symbols /* and */ even if they are placed on differing lines.[/!] [!python]a line beginning with ''' until the next line ending with '''.[/!]
methodCallReadByThe[!java|scala|c]Compiler[/!][!python]Interpreter[/!]()[!java|c];[/!] [!java|scala|c]//[/!][!python]#[/!] all this is ignored
otherCall()[!java|c];[/!] [!java|scala|c]/* This is
               also ignored */[/!]
[!python]''' This is
also ignored  '''[/!]
yetAnotherCall()[!java|c];[/!]

There is a third kind of comments in Java, between /** and */, which are read by a specific program called JavaDoc to generate automatically the documentation explaining how to use the code. These comments must follow a very precise formalism.

The comments on several lines are often used to document how to use the code, while others are more used to describe how this code works.
instructions.fr:
crire des programmes plus complexes

Maintenant que vous savez crire des choses sur le sol, nous allons utiliser cette comptence pour dessiner un merveilleux G par terre. Consultez le panneau d'objectif pour les dtails de ce qui est attendu.

Quand vous crivez un programme un peu complexe, il est souvent pratique d'ajouter des commentaires pour simplifier la relecture du code aprs coup. Ici par exemple, il est assez facile de se perdre dans les ordres ncessaires au dessin. Il peut tre pratique d'ajouter des commentaires comme fin de la barre verticale ou Fini de dessiner le G. Retournons la position initiale. Documenter votre code est presque toujours ncessaire si quelqu'un (vous ou quelqu'un d'autre) veut le lire aprs coup. Cependant, sur-commenter des choses triviales est une mauvaise ide car cela dilue les informations dans des commentaires trop verbeux.

Il y a [!java]trois[/!][!python|scala|c]deux[/!] sortes de commentaires en [!thelang], indiquant [!java|scala|c]au compilateur[/!][!python] l'interprteur[/!] qu'il ne doit pas lire le texte ajout pour les humains.

  • Commentaires sur une seule ligne. Quand le [!java|scala|c]compilateur[/!][!python]interprteur[/!] rencontre le symbole [!java|scala|c]//[/!][!python]#[/!], il ignore la fin de la ligne.
  • Commentaires sur plusieurs lignes. [!java|scala|c]Le compilateur[/!][!python]L'interprteur[/!] ignore tout ce qui se trouve entre [!java|scala|c]les symboles /* et */, mme s'ils sont sur des lignes diffrentes.[/!] [!python]une ligne commenant par ''' et la prochaine ligne terminant par '''.[/!]
methodeAppeleeParLe[!java|scala|c]Compilateur[/!][!python]Interpreteur[/!]()[!java|c];[/!] [!java|scala|c]//[/!][!python]#[/!] tout ceci est ignor
autreAppel()[!java|c];[/!] [!java|scala|c]/* Ceci est
               galement ignor */[/!]
[!python]''' Ceci est
galement ignor '''[/!]
encoreUneAutreAppel()[!java|c];[/!]

Il existe une troisime forme de commentaires en Java, entre /** et */, qui sont lus par un programme nomm JavaDoc pour gnrer automatiquement la documentation expliquant comment utiliser le code. Ces commentaires doivent suivre un formalisme prcis.

Les commentaires sur plusieurs lignes sont souvent utiliss pour documenter comment utiliser le code, tandis que les autres types de commentaires sont souvent utiliss pour documenter comment le code fonctionne.
